messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Re: Question for Oldtimers -I can do guns, it's t...
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 12/8/03 5:28:57 AM, HMSL2@aol.com writes:
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 12/8/03 5:28:57 AM, HMSL2@... writes:

<< But why on
earth would someone comment on your families choice or husbands for that
matter to
get a vc? >>

Because if a church is preaching something, it's not that family's choice any
more. It's God's will. And people who aren't going to do God's will (as
revealed by the interpretation of the minister of the church they go to) are
disruptive and problematical, so the best thing to do is to bring them into line.

That sheep and shepherd analogy is big with fundamentalist Christians.

Sandra

messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Re: Question for Oldtimers -I can do guns, it's t...
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 12/8/2003 11:38:32 AM Eastern Standard Time, mamabethuscg@yahoo.com writes: So by admitting that my husband had a vasectomy, even for
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 12/8/2003 11:38:32 AM Eastern Standard Time,
mamabethuscg@... writes:
So by admitting that my husband had a vasectomy, even for reasons to us that
are biblical (his role as husband to protect me from dangerous situations)
others felt they had the right to condemn us for because as Christians we are
told to speak to one another if we see that another is doing something "wrong."

MamaBeth
I have to say in my fundamentalist Baptist Church that does NOT happen at
all. No one would presume to tell you to have or not have more children.

I have always accepted my children as a blessing from God. My DH had a
vasectomy, I don't even know if the "church" as a body knows or would even care to
know. We do NOT discuss as a general rule things like that with the entire
church body and I don't hear it from anyone else.

Must just be SOME of the Christian groups that do that. Like with everything
in life, there is a broad spectrum of how people chose to live their lives.

glena

messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Re: Question for Oldtimers -I can do guns, it's t...
messages.msgSnippet: Yes, quiver full is a term in some Christian circles regarding how many children a family has. Basically the theology is that birth control of any kind is
messages.messageBody:
Yes, "quiver full" is a term in some Christian circles regarding how many children a family has.

Basically the theology is that birth control of any kind is wrong, and that God will provide the means to take care of any children He may bless you with. Some see it as wrong even where health concerns make it difficult for the mother to be pregnant, because to them it means you must not be trusting in Him fully.

So by admitting that my husband had a vasectomy, even for reasons to us that are biblical (his role as husband to protect me from dangerous situations) others felt they had the right to condemn us for because as Christians we are told to speak to one another if we see that another is doing something "wrong."

MamaBeth




Everything I need to know, I learned on my own!

messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Re: Question for Oldtimers -I can do guns, it's t...
messages.msgSnippet: Quiver full as in children? Front page of AOL yesterday said 4 or more children is a status thing with the more affluent families.  Its my experience that the
messages.messageBody:
Quiver full as in children? Front page of AOL yesterday said 4 or more
children is a status thing with the more affluent families. Its my experience that
the thought is the more the merrier in the Christian circles. But why on
earth would someone comment on your families choice or husbands for that matter to
get a vc?
Laura
<<< Mamabeth writes:
>I have seen quite a bit in my Christian circles about being "quiver-full"
although I >never realized (or was told) that there was actually a book about
the subject. That being >said, I'd have as many children as God would bless me
with if it wasn't hazardous to my >health to do so! I have been slammed in
some circles for agreeing with my husband's >decision to have a vasectomy
because of the QF ideals...
I'm finding this bizarre. I've never encountered this with the Christans I
know here (I'm beginning to exclude myself from the christian label I think).
Are Canadian christians more moderate? Or just Nova Scotian ones? Or is this
QF idea just a fundamental idea?

Dawn (who knows most Christians she knows would laugh at the QF idea)
